original.definition: get together socially or for a specific purpose

sememes.reasoning: The definition 'get together socially' describes a transition from a state of non-connection to one of social connection or interaction.

participants.reasoning: The 'Somebody' who is one of the participants initiating or taking part in the social gathering.
The 'PP' in the frame often refers to the other person or group with whom the 'Somebody' is getting together, essential for the meaning of 'meet'.

sememes.reasoning: The definition explicitly states 'socially or for a specific purpose', indicating the inherent nature of the meeting.

Evidentiality.reasoning: Meeting is a directly observable event or interaction.

Mood.reasoning: The verb's core meaning is declarative, stating an event or action.

Modality.reasoning: The presence of 'Somebody' in the frame indicates an agent acting with will and intention.

Polarity.reasoning: The act of meeting is inherently neutral; its sentiment depends on the context or purpose.

Volitionality.reasoning: The frame 'Somebody ----s PP' clearly indicates a volitional agent performing the action of meeting.

Confidence.reasoning: The verb describes a definite occurrence of getting together.

Iterativity.reasoning: The lexeme describes a single event of getting together, though it can be repeated, the verb itself does not imply inherent repetition for a single usage.

candidates.description: an exclusive informal network linking members of a social class or profession or organization in order to provide connections and information and favors (especially in business or politics) (gloss match)

candidates.description: a game in which participants compete to identify some obscurely indicated thing (gloss match)
a lottery in which the prize consists of the money paid by the participants (gloss match)
a system of conduct in which participants are trusted not to take unfair advantage of others (gloss match)

a fraudulent scheme in which people are recruited to make payments to the person who recruited them while expecting to receive payments from the persons they recruit; when the number of new recruits fails to sustain the hierarchical payment structure the scheme collapses with most of the participants losing the money they put in (gloss match)

the function of pointing or specifying from the perspective of a participant in an act of speech or writing; aspects of a communication whose interpretation depends on knowledge of the context in which the communication occurs (gloss match)
(psychology) bias introduced by an experimenter whose expectations about the outcome of the experiment can be subtly communicated to the participants in the experiment (gloss match)
a court order restricting information or comment by the participants involved in a lawsuit (gloss match)
a central collection place where banks exchange checks or drafts; participants maintain an account against which credits or debits are posted (gloss match)
a meeting or conference for the public discussion of some topic especially one in which the participants form an audience and make presentations (gloss match)
an important participant (as in a business deal) (gloss match)
childbirth during which the mother is encouraged to be an active participant (gloss match)
an economic condition that results in the elimination of marginally financed participants in an industry (gloss match)

participants.corrected_reasoning: LLM suggestion: 'participant.n.01' is the most general and appropriate semantic role representing someone involved in an action, fitting the intent of 'co_participant.n.01'.
